p.seg: Therefore (the sage kings) were careful judges of their conduct, and sincere in their orders,
"determine the relations of high and low; they are the warp and woof of Heaven and Earth;
It has lost its (proper) rules (of administration).
It is not that Zhu presumes to be worried about itself
Duke Yin
B *Commentary*
B1 Duke Hui's primary wife was Mengzi.
After Mengzi died,
she was succeeded by Shengzi as his secondary wife,
who gave birth to Duke Yin.
Duke Wu of Song gave birth to Zhongzi.
When Zhongzi was born, there was a mark on her hand
that said, "She will be the Lady of Lu,"
therefore, Zhongzi was sent to us [Lu].
She gave birth to Duke Huan, and Duke Hui died,
therefore, Duke Yin was established [as ruler] and served her [Zhongzi].
A1.1 *Annals of Duke Yin, Year 1*
A1.1.1 In the first year, in spring, the king's first month.
A1.1.2 In the third month,
the Duke and Yi Fu of Zhu made a covenant at Mie.
A1.1.3 In summer, the fifth month,
the Earl of Zheng overcame Duan at Yan.
A1.1.4 In autumn, the seventh month,
the King sent Zai Xuan to return the gifts for Duke Hui and
Zhongzi's burial.
A1.1.5 In the ninth month,
(Duke Yin) and the people of Song made a covenant at Su.
A1.1.6 In the twelfth month of winter,
Ji Bo came.
A1.1.7 Gongzi Yishi died.
B1.1 *The Commentary to the First Year of Duke Yin*
B1.1.1 In the first year, in the spring,
the royal Zhou first month,
his enthronement was not recorded,
because he was acting as regent.
B1.1.2 In the third month,
the Duke and Yi Fu of Zhu made a covenant at Mie.
He was Ke, the Viscount of Zhu.
Because it was not by royal command,
his rank was not recorded.
He is called "Yi Fu"
to show respect to him.
Because the Duke was acting as regent and wished to seek amity with Zhu,
therefore he made the covenant at Mie.
B1.1.3 In the fourth month of summer,
Fei Bo led troops to fortify Lang.
It was not recorded,
because it was not by the Duke's order.
B1.1.4 Initially,
Duke Wu of Zheng married a woman from Shen,
named Wu Jiang.
She gave birth to Duke Zhuang and Gongshu Duan.
Duke Zhuang was born feet first (lit., born waking),
which startled Lady Jiang.
Therefore, he was named Wusheng (lit., Awoken at Birth),
and consequently, she disliked him.
She loved Gongshu Duan
and wanted to establish him as the heir.
She frequently pleaded with Duke Wu,
but the Duke did not permit it.
When Duke Zhuang ascended the throne,
she requested the fief of Zhi for him.
The Duke said,
"Zhi
is a fortified city;
Guo Shu died there.
Other cities, I will grant according to decree."
She requested Jing
and had him reside there,
calling him Grand Uncle of Jingcheng.
Ji Zhong said,
"A capital city
exceeding one hundred *zhi* in circumference
is a danger to the state.
The regulations of the former kings are:
a large capital city
should not exceed one-third the size of the state;
Middle,
one-fifth;
small,
one-ninth.
Now, the capital exceeding the limit,
is not in accordance with the regulations,
your Lordship will not be able to endure it."
The Duke said:
"Jiang desires it,
how can I avoid harming her?"
He replied:
"How can Jiang ever be satisfied?
It is better to make provisions for him early,
do not allow it to spread!
Once it spreads,
it will be difficult to deal with.
Even spreading weeds cannot be removed,
how much more so your Lordship's favored younger brother?"
The Duke said:
"One who commits many injustices will surely bring about his own downfall,
you just wait and see."
Later, Uncle commanded the western and northern borders to be disloyal to the Duke and loyal to himself.
Gongzi Lü said:
"The state cannot bear disloyalty,
what will your Lordship do?
If you intend to give it to Uncle,
I request to serve him;
if you do not give it to him,
then please remove him,
so as not to stir the people's hearts."
The Duke said,
"No need,
he will bring it upon himself."
The Grand Uncle further seized Er as his own city,
reaching as far as Lin Yan.
Zi Feng said,
"It is permissible.
Great generosity will win over the masses."
The Duke said,
"It is unrighteous,
and does not foster affection.
Great generosity will lead to collapse."
The Grand Uncle fortified and amassed resources,
repaired armor and weapons,
prepared soldiers and chariots,
intending to attack Zheng.
The Lady was going to open the gates for him.
The Duke heard of the planned date,
and said,
"It is permissible."
He ordered Zi Feng to lead two hundred chariots to attack Jing.
Jing rebelled against Grand Uncle Duan.
Duan fled into Yan.
The Duke attacked him at Yan.
On the Xin Chou day of the fifth month,
Grand Uncle fled to Gong.
The *Book of Documents* says:
"The Earl of Zheng conquered Duan at Yan."
Duan was not a good younger brother,
therefore, it does not say "younger brother";
treating them as two rulers,
therefore it says "conquered";
calling him "Earl of Zheng,"
criticizes his failure to teach (his brother);
this is called the Zheng record.
It does not say "fled,"
because it was difficult to say so.
Then he placed Lady Jiang in the city of Ying,
and swore an oath to her, saying:
"Until we reach the Yellow Springs,
we shall not see each other!"
Afterwards, he regretted it.
Ying Kao-shu was the border official of Ying Valley.
Hearing of this,
he made an offering to the duke.
The duke gave him food.
He left the meat uneaten.
The duke asked him about it.
He replied:
"I, a humble man, have a mother,
who has always tasted my food;
she has never tasted the duke's soup,
I beg to give it to her."
The duke said:
"You have a mother to leave behind,
but I alone have none!"
Ying Kao Shu said:
"May I venture to ask what you mean?"
The Duke told him the reason
and also told him of his regret.
He replied:
"What does Your Lordship have to worry about?
If you dig a tunnel reaching to the spring,
and meet her through it,
who would say it is not right?"
The Duke followed his advice.
The Duke entered and recited:
"Within the great tunnel,
the joy is harmonious."
Jiang came out and recited:
"Outside the great tunnel,
the joy is overflowing."
Thereupon, they became as mother and son as before.
The gentleman said:
"Ying Kao Shu
was truly filial.
He loved his mother
and extended that love to Duke Zhuang.
The *Book of Poetry* says:
'A filial son is never deficient;
he will forever bestow blessings on your kind.'
That is what this refers to!"
B1.1.5 In the seventh month of autumn,
the King of Heaven sent the steward Xuan to bring the gifts (賵) for Duke Hui and Zhongzi.
It was slow (緩),
and furthermore, the Zi clan woman had not yet died,
therefore they are named.
The Son of Heaven is buried in the seventh month,
and those who share the same tracks (同軌, i.e., those under his direct administration) all arrive;
the feudal lords in the fifth month,
and those of the same alliance (同盟) arrive;
the grand officers in the third month,
and those of the same rank (同位) arrive;
the officers after a month,
and relatives by marriage (外姻) arrive.
To make gifts for the dead before the body is present,
to express condolences to the living before mourning begins,
and to anticipate calamitous events
is contrary to propriety.
B1.1.6 In the eighth month,
the people of Ji attacked the Yi.
The Yi did not report it,
therefore it was not recorded.
B1.1.7 There were locusts (蜚).
Because they did not cause disaster,
it also was not recorded.
B1.1.8 In the later years of Duke Hui,
he defeated the Song army at Huang.
After the Duke (Yin) ascended (to the throne), he sought peace.
In the ninth month,
In the ninth month,
(our lord) and the men of Song made a covenant at Su,
and intercourse (between the states) began.
B1.1.9 In the tenth month, on the day Gengshen,
they reburied Duke Hui.
The Duke did not attend,
therefore it is not recorded.
At the time of Duke Hui's death,
there were Song troops (present),
and the heir apparent was young,
so the burial was deficient.
Therefore, they reburied him.
B1.1.10 The Marquis of Wei came to attend the funeral,
but did not see the Duke,
so it is also not recorded.
B1.1.11 In the Zheng Gongshu Rebellion,
Gongsun Hua fled to Wei.
The men of Wei attacked Zheng on his behalf,
and took Linyan.
The men of Zheng, with the king's army and
the Guo army, attacked the southern border of Wei.
He requested troops from Zhu.
The Viscount of Zhu employed someone to privately petition Gongzi Yu.
Yu requested to go,
but the Duke did not permit it.
He then went,
and he and the men of Zhu and
the men of Zheng made a covenant at Yi.
Not recorded,
because it was not by the duke's command.
B1.1.12 The new construction of the south gate,
not recorded,
also because it was not by the duke's command.
B1.1.13 In the twelfth month,
the sacrificial envoy Bo came,
not by the king's command.
B1.1.14 When Zhongfu died,
the duke did not participate in the small encoffining,
therefore the date was not recorded.
A1.2 *Duke Yin, Year 2 Chronicle*
A1.2.1 In the second year, spring,
the duke met with the Rong people at Qian.
A1.2.2 In summer, the fifth month,
the people of Ju entered Xiang.
A1.2.3 Wu Hai led an army to enter Ji.
A1.2.4 In autumn, the eighth month, on the day Gengchen,
the duke and the Rong made an alliance at Tang.
A1.2.5 In the ninth month,
Ji Liexu came to escort the daughter.
A1.2.6 In winter, the tenth month,
Bo Ji was married to Ji.
A1.2.7 The Viscount of Ji and the Viscount of Ju made a covenant at Mi.
A1.2.8 In the twelfth month, on the day Yimao, Lady Zishi passed away.
A1.2.9 The people of Zheng attacked Wei.
B1.2 *The Commentary of the Second Year of Duke Yin*
B1.2.1 In the second year, in spring, the Duke met with the Rong at Qian, to renew the friendship of Duke Hui.
The Rong requested a covenant, but the Duke declined.
B1.2.2 The Viscount of Ju married from Xiang. Xiang Jiang was uneasy in Ju and returned.
In summer, the people of Ju entered Xiang, and brought back the Jiang woman.
B1.2.3 Sikong Wuhai entered Ji, and Fei Qin Fu defeated him.
B1.2.4 The Rong requested a covenant.
In autumn, they made a covenant at Tang, renewing the friendship with the Rong.
B1.2.5 In the ninth month, Ji Liexu came to escort the bride; a卿 *qing* official escorting on behalf of the ruler.
Ji Liexu came to meet the daughter (in marriage).
As a卿 (high minister), he met her on behalf of the ruler.
B1.2.6 In winter,
Viscount Bo of Ji
and the Viscount of Ju
formed an alliance at Mi,
because of Lu.
B1.2.7 The people of Zheng attacked Wei
to punish the rebellion of Gongsun Hua.
A1.3 *The Annals of Duke Yin, Year Three*
A1.3.1 In the spring of the third year, the king's second month,
on the day of Ji-si,
there was a solar eclipse.
A1.3.2 In the third month, on the day of Geng-xu,
the Heavenly King passed away.
A1.3.3 In the summer, the fourth month, on the day of Xin-mao,
the Lady of the Ruler passed away.
A1.3.4 In the autumn,
the son of the Wu lineage came seeking funeral contributions.
A1.3.5 In the eighth month, on the day of Geng-chen,
Duke Mu of Song, He, passed away.
A1.3.6 In the winter, the twelfth month,
The Marquis of Qi and
the Earl of Zheng formed an alliance at Shimen.
A1.3.7 On Guiwei
, the Duke Mu of Song was buried.
B1.3 *Zuo Zhuan*, Year 3 of Duke Yin
B1.3.1 In the spring of the third year,
in the third month of the king,
on Renxu,
King Ping died.
The report of his death arrived on Gengxu,
therefore it is recorded.
B1.3.2 In summer,
the Lady of the Ruler died.
-- This was the Lady Sheng.
There was no announcement of her death to the feudal lords,
no returning to the bedchamber to mourn,
and no spirit tablet placed with her husband's aunt,
therefore it is not said
"薨" (died, used for nobles).
She is not referred to as "夫人" (Lady),
therefore her burial is not mentioned,
and her surname is not written.
Because of the Duke's sake,
it is said
"the Lady of the Ruler".
B1.3.3 Duke Wu and Duke Zhuang of Zheng
served as ministers to King Ping.
The King showed favoritism to Guo.
The Earl of Zheng resented the King.
The King said,
"There is no such thing."
Therefore, Zhou and Zheng exchanged hostages.
Prince Hu of the King was a hostage in Zheng,
and Gongzi Hu of Zheng was a hostage in Zhou.
The King died.
The people of Zhou were about to give the government to the Duke of Guo.
In the fourth month,
Zheng Jizu led troops to take the wheat of Wen.
In the autumn,
he also took the grain of Chengzhou.
Zhou and Zheng became enemies.
A gentleman said:
"If trust does not come from within,
hostages are of no benefit.
If one acts with understanding and forgiveness,
and regulates conduct with propriety,
even without hostages,
who can sow discord?
If there is genuine trust,
even the fur from streams, brooks,
ponds, and islets,
the duckweed, white artemisia,
and pondweed from swamps,
Baskets, hampers,
tripods, and cauldrons,
stagnant puddles, foul water,
and water flowing after rain,
can be offered to spirits,
and presented to kings and dukes.
How much more so when a gentleman establishes trust between two states
and conducts affairs with propriety,
what need is there for oaths?
The *Airs* contain "Gathering the White Artemisia"
and "Gathering the Duckweed,"
the *Odes* contain "Rows of Reeds"
and "Drawing from the Deep Well,"
which demonstrate loyalty and trustworthiness."
B1.3.4 A son of the Wu family came seeking aid for burial,
but the king had not yet been buried.
B1.3.5 Duke Mu of Song fell ill,
and summoned the Grand Marshal Kong Fu
to entrust the infant Duke Shang to him,
saying:
"The former lord abandoned Yu and Yi and established me,
which I dare not forget.
If by the spirits of the high officials
I can preserve my head and body until death,
should the former lord ask about Yu and Yi,
what excuse shall I use to answer?
I ask you to support him
and make him the master of the altars of the soil and grain.
Though I die,
I will have no regrets."
The ministers replied,
"Your servants wish to support Feng."
The Duke said,
"That cannot be.
The late ruler considered me virtuous
and appointed me to govern the state.
If I abandon virtue and do not yield,
it would be overturning the late ruler's decision.
How could I be called virtuous?
To brightly illuminate the late ruler's virtuous commands,
how can I not strive for that?
My sons, do not abandon the late ruler's accomplishments!"
He had Gongzi Feng go and reside in Zheng.
On the day Gengchen of the eighth month,
Duke Mu of Song died,
and Duke Shang took the throne.
A gentleman said,
"Duke Xuan of Song can be said to have known men well.
He established Duke Mu,
and his son enjoyed (the benefits of it).
His appointment was indeed righteous!
The *Shang Song* says,
'Yin received the mandate and was entirely suitable;
it bore the hundred blessings.'
Is it not referring to this!"
B1.3.6 In winter,
Qi and Zheng formed an alliance at Shimen,
which was a continuation of the alliance at Lu.
On the day of Gengxu,
the carriage of the Count of Zheng overturned in the Ji River.
B1.3.7 Duke Zhuang of Wei married the younger sister of Minister Dechen of the Qi Eastern Palace,
named Zhuang Jiang,
who was beautiful but had no children.
The people of Wei composed the "Shuo Ren" (Ode to the Tall and Handsome Lady) for her.
He also married a woman from Chen,
named Li Gui,
who gave birth to Xiao Bo,
who died young.
Her younger sister, Dai Gui,
gave birth to Duke Huan,
whom Zhuang Jiang considered her own son.
Gongzi (Lord) Zhou Yu
was the son of a concubine.
He was favored and loved military affairs,
but the Duke did not restrain him.
Zhuang Jiang detested him.
Shi Que advised,
"I have heard that if you love your son,
you should teach him with righteous principles,
and not let him fall into evil.
Arrogance, extravagance, licentiousness, and dissipation
are where evil comes from.
These four things arise
when favor and emoluments are excessive.
To establish Duke Zhou Xu,
he had already decided upon it.
If it still isn't right,
this will be the stepping stone to disaster.
Now, one who is favored but not arrogant,
arrogant but able to humble himself,
humbled but without resentment,
resentful but able to reflect,
is rare indeed.
Moreover, for the lowly to obstruct the noble,
the young to insult the old,
the distant to alienate the close,
the new to estrange the old,
the small to encroach upon the large,
and indulgence to destroy righteousness,
these are the so-called six rebellions.
The ruler being righteous,
the ministers acting accordingly,
the father being kind,
the son being filial,
the elder brother being loving,
the younger brother being respectful,
these are the so-called six obediences.
To abandon obedience and imitate rebellion
is how one hastens disaster.
A ruler,
whose duty it is to eliminate disaster,
yet hastens it,
Wouldn't that be unacceptable?"
He did not listen.
His son, Hou, associated with Zhou Yu.
He forbade it,
but it was not possible (to stop him).
When Duke Huan was established,
he retired.
A1.4 *Annals of Duke Yin, Year 4*
A1.4.1 In the fourth year, spring,
in the second month of the king,
The people of Ju attacked Qi,
and took Mou Lou.
A1.4.2 On the day of Wushen,
Zhou Yu of Wei murdered his lord, Wan.
A1.4.3 In summer,
the Duke met with the Duke of Song at Qing.
A1.4.4 The Duke of Song,
the Marquis of Chen,
the people of Cai,
and the people of Wei attacked Zheng.
A1.4.5 In autumn,
Hui led troops to join the Duke of Song,
the Marquis of Chen,
the people of Cai,
and the people of Wei to attack Zheng.
A1.4.6 In the ninth month,
the people of Wei killed Zhou Yu at Pu.
A1.4.7 In the twelfth month of winter,
the people of Wei installed Jin.
B1.4 *Commentary on the Fourth Year of Duke Yin*
B1.4.1 In the spring of the fourth year,
Zhou Yu of Wei murdered Duke Huan and established himself.
B1.4.2 The Duke held a meeting with the Duke of Song,
intending to renew the alliance of Su.
Before the appointed time arrived,
the people of Wei came to report the rebellion.
In summer,
the Duke (Yin) and the Duke of Song met in Qing.
B1.4.3 When Duke Shang of Song ascended the throne,
Gongzi Feng fled to Zheng.
The people of Zheng wanted to install him.
After Zhou Xu of Wei came to power,
he intended to avenge the former ruler's grievances against Zheng
and seek favor from the lords,
in order to pacify his people.
He sent a message to Song, saying:
"If Your Lordship attacks Zheng
to remove your enemy,
Your Lordship will be the leader,
and our humble state will provide resources and join with Chen and
Cai to follow.
This is the wish of the state of Wei."
The people of Song agreed to this.
There was a man from the state of Guo named Gongsun Youshan.
B12.27.5 In the fourth year of Duke Dao,
the Jin general Xun Yao led an army to besiege Zheng.
Before they arrived,
Zheng's Si Hong said,
"Zhi Bo is stubborn and loves to win.
If we submit to him early,
it will be feasible."
So he first fortified Nanli to await him.
Zhi Bo entered Nanli
and approached the gate of Jiezhi.
The people of Zheng captured Xukui Leilei,
bribed him with knowledge of the government,
sealed his mouth, and then killed him.
When Zhi Bo was about to enter the gate, he asked,
"Open it and let me in!"
The guard replied,
"The ruler is here."
Zhi Bo said,
"To be disliked and without courage,
how can you be considered a son?"
The guard replied,
"By being able to endure shame,
perhaps I can prevent harm to the Zhao lineage!"
Zhi Bo did not repent.
Zhao Xiangzi therefore harbored resentment towards Zhi Bo,
and ultimately destroyed him.
Zhi Bo was greedy and stubborn,
therefore Han
and Wei rebelled against him and caused his downfall.
it is not recorded in the records.
B1.11.8 Yu Fu requested to kill Duke Huan,
intending to seek the position of Grand Minister.
The Duke said,
"Because he is young,
I intend to bestow it upon him."
I will have him build Tuqiu,
and I will retire there."
Yu Fu was afraid,
and instead slandered the Duke to Duke Huan and requested to assassinate him.
When the Duke was a young master,
he fought with the people of Zheng at Huyang,
and stopped there.
The people of Zheng imprisoned him in the Yin family.
He bribed the Yin family,
and prayed to their master, the sorcerer Zhong Wu.
Then he returned with the Yin family,
and established their master.
In the eleventh month,
the Duke sacrificed to the sorcerer Zhong Wu,
prepared himself at the altar in the garden,
and lodged at the Wei family.
On the day of Ren Chen,
Yu Fu sent assassins to kill the Duke at the Wei family,
and established Duke Huan,
and punished the Wei family,
causing deaths.
There was no record of the burial,
so the mourning was incomplete.
Duke Huan
A2.1 *Huan Gong Yuan Nian Jing* (Annals of the First Year of Duke Huan)
A2.1.1 In the first year, spring,
The Marquis of Xi attacked Zheng.
The Earl of Zheng fought with him at the border,
and the Xi army was utterly defeated and returned.
This is how the gentleman knew that Xi was about to perish:
"Not assessing virtue,
not measuring strength,
is not intimate with his relatives,
does not verify his words,
and does not investigate the guilty.
He commits these five unrighteous acts
and uses them to attack others.
It is no surprise that he loses his army,
is it not fitting?"
B1.11.7 In the tenth month of winter,
the Count of Zheng, with the army of Guo, attacked Song.
On the day *renxu*,
he greatly defeated the Song army,
in order to avenge their entry into Zheng.
Song did not report this order,
therefore it was not recorded.
Whenever the feudal lords had an order,
if it was reported, it was recorded;
otherwise, it was not.
Whether an army is successful or not,
it is also the same.
Even regarding the destruction of a state,
if the vanquished does not report their defeat,
or the victor does not report their victory,
and punishments are for correcting evil.
Since he has neither virtuous governance
nor awe-inspiring punishments,
this is how he allows evil to flourish.
Having allowed evil to flourish, he then curses it;
what benefit will this bring?"
B1.11.5 King (Huan of Zhou) took the fields of Wu,
Liu, Wei,
and Yu from Zheng,
and gave the people of Zheng the fields of Su Fen-sheng:
Wen, Yuan,
Chi, Fan,
Xi Cheng,
Zuan Mao,
Xiang, Meng,
Zhou, Xing,
Tui, and Huai.
This is how the gentleman knew
that King Huan had lost Zheng.
To be forgiving and act accordingly
is the model of virtue,
the principle of propriety.
To not be able to possess something oneself
yet give it to others,
is it not fitting that people do not come [to support you]?
B1.11.6 Zheng and
Xi had conflicting words.
The royal house is already degraded.
The descendants of Zhou are daily losing their order.
Xu,
is a descendant of the Great Mountain.
If Heaven is already tired of the virtue of Zhou,
how can I contend with Xu?"
The gentleman said that Duke Zhuang of Zheng
"in this matter, he possessed ritual propriety.
Ritual propriety
manages the state,
stabilizes the altars of the soil and grain,
orders the people,
benefits future generations.
Xu
was attacked without being formally charged,
he conquered them and then released them,
he assessed his virtue and then took his position,
he measured his strength and then acted.
He moved in accordance with the times,
without burdening future generations;
he can be said to know ritual propriety."
B1.11.4 Duke Zheng ordered his soldiers to release a boar,
and lead out dogs
and chickens,
in order to curse those who shot Ying Kaoshu.
The gentleman said that Duke Zhuang of Zheng
"has lost his governance and punishments.
Governance is for ruling the people,
how dare I take Xu as my own merit?
I have a younger brother [Duke Duan of Gong],
who is unable to be harmonious and cooperative,
and has been forced to make a living in all four directions,
how could I possibly hold Xu for long?
May you, sir, uphold Xu,"
Shu in comforting and pacifying this people.
I will have Huo assist you.
If I should be buried in the ground,
may Heaven, according to ritual, avert misfortune from Xu.
Would it not be better for the current Lord of Xu to once again uphold his altars of soil and grain,
so that only my Zheng state would have requests to make of him,
as in the old days of marriage alliances,
if he could condescend to follow our lead.
Do not let other clans take root here and crowd this place,
to contend with my Zheng state for this land.
My descendants will not even have time to avoid ruin,
how much less will they be able to sacrifice to Xu?
My sending you to stay here,
is not only for the sake of Xu,
but also to strengthen my borders."
Thereupon, he sent Gongsun Huo to reside in the western part of Xu,
and said:
"All your implements, utensils, and wealth,
do not place them in Xu.
When I die,
then leave quickly!
My late lord established a new city here.
On the day Geng-chen,
they arrived near Xu.
Ying Kao Shu took the Earl of Zheng's flag (decorated with a) mao hu (蝥弧)
to be the first to climb the city wall,
Zi Du shot at him from below,
and he fell.
Xia Shuying then used the *maohu* to climb,
waved the Zhou banner and shouted,
"The ruler has ascended!"
The Zheng army all then climbed up.
On the day *renwu*,
they finally entered Xu.
Duke Zhuang of Xu fled to Wei.
The Marquis of Qi wanted to cede Xu to Duke Yin of Lu.
Duke Yin said,
"You, my lord, said that Xu was disobedient,
therefore I followed you to punish it.
Xu has already submitted to its punishment,
even if you, my lord, have an order,
I, your subject, dare not participate in it."
So he gave it to the people of Zheng.
The Zheng ruler ordered the Xu grand master Baili to escort Xu Shu
